Award.AwardTitle: Tropical Storms: A Bridge Between Formation and Intensification
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract for Barnes/1042680

Over the last decade efforts by NOAA and cooperating federal agencies have provided observations during progressively earlier stages of the hurricane life cycle. Tropical storms (TS, which are named systems possessing sustained wind speeds of 17-32 m/s) have thus been more frequently observed via a combination of in-situ airborne sensors, Global Positioning System (GPS) dropwindsondes, and airborne conventional and Doppler radar. Existing data archives maintained by NOAA, NASA and the USAF Hurricane Reconnaissance Squadron represent key sources of information for this study, and their further exploitation is offers a desirably economical approach. Persistent uncertainties concerning mechanisms of TS formation and subsequent rapid intensification represent an impediment to more accurate forecasts and warnings; more complete examination of aforementioned datasets may provide insights into TS formation, the subsequent evolution of these warm-core storms, and ultimately those processes responsible for development of higher-category hurricanes. Detailed atmospheric profiles obtained by arrays of GPS sondes will be objectively combined flight-level and volumetric radar data within 200 km of the center of developing TS events with a focus on lower tropospheric structures and near-surface storm inflow. Serial reconnaissance flights by the USAF offer desirable temporal resolution (viz. snapshots very 6-12 hours). Global reanalysis datasets will be used to describe the large-scale environment of the storms. Together these fields will reveal further details re: the influence of environmental factors such as the deep layer vertical shear of the horizontal wind and midlevel dry air upon internal storm features including the developing circular eyewall and enclosed eye region, spiral rainbands, and associated energy inputs into the atmospheric boundary layer.

The Intellectual Merit of this study rests in attaining more comprehensive descriptions of: reflectivity, kinematic and thermodynamic structures within developing tropical storms; the source of increased equivalent potential temperature near the storm core and its role in the formation process; the disposition of warm, moist low-level inflow directed toward the developing core; and the role of the mesoscale convectively generated vortex in TS development. Competing theories of TS formation (viz. so-called "top-down" or "bottom-up" mechanisms) will be critically evaluated using these previously untapped observations, and conditions differentiating tropical storms that attain hurricane status and those that do not will be explored. Derived fields will serve as a benchmark for detailed numerical simulations of tropical storms.

Broader Impacts of this work will be derived through the training of graduate students and the continued development of classes in tropical meteorology offered at the University of Hawaii, by enhancement of a existing partnerships between the University of Hawaii and NOAA's Hurricane Research Division, and ultimately through improved ability to better anticipate hurricane development and issue accurate warnings to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are two outstanding problems with regard to hurricane research: (1) what causes hurricanes to form and (2) what controls their maximum sustained winds, aka intensity. This award from NSF addresses both of these issues. In 2001 NASA and NOAA aircraft sampled Hurricane Humberto over three consecutive days as it developed from a weak tropical storm to hurricane (75 mph sustained winds) intensity. The aircraft collected radar observations and deployed 228 Global Positioning System dropwindsondes (GPS sondes) within 250 km of the circulation center of the storm. These GPS sondes supply wind and thermodynamic data every half second as they fall from the aircraft to the sea surface. At the time Humberto was the best sampled storm with GPS sondes in history.  

The hallmark trait of a hurricane is the column of warm air that causes the pressure to decrease with the greatest drop occurring at the sea surface. This decrease in pressure in the eye and eyewall results in large horizontal pressure differences between the storm center and the more distant environment which in turn drives the winds to destructive speeds. The observations on the first day reveal that the initial warming occurs in the lower troposphere, underneath an anvil cloud in light rain. The warming is caused by subsiding air. This layer of warmer air lowers the pressure by a few millibars and creates the nascent circulation center. In the lowest km or so air swirls cyclonically and inward toward the center in response to the lower pressure. This air gains energy in the form of greater amounts of water vapor and temperature from the adjacent warm ocean. Increases in energy content are vital to the formation of a hurricane. This higher energy air did not immediately ascend because it is trapped underneath the inversion caused by the subsiding air above. The air near the surface thus could increase its energy to a substantial level without being transferred by deep convective clouds through the entire troposphere. When it finally ascends in deep clouds it is able to accelerate upward and in doing so concentrates the cyclonic spin caused by the initial lowering of the surface pressure. The Humberto analyses are perhaps the best view of the developmental stages of a real hurricane the community has to date.  The warm core is shown to appear first in the lower troposphere and then expands aloft. Mature hurricanes generally have their warmest air in the upper troposphere. Figure 1 shows the warm core temperature anomaly (excess temperature compared to the surrounding region) on the first day.

 Analyses of the flights on the following two days reveal details about how the hurricane responds to increased vertical shear of the horizontal wind, commonly referred to as vertical wind shear. Strong vertical wind shear simply means that the wind direction and speed varies as one ascends. This causes the warm column in the hurricane center to either be tilted from a vertical alignment or to mix cooler and drier environmental air into the warm core. Either situation will weaken the hurricane. For Humberto vertical wind shear from the surface to the middle of the troposphere results in mixing of cool, dry air into the eyewall. This lowers the energy of the column and causes the central pressure to rise, weakening the storm. The vertical wind shear also makes the eyewall more asymmetric, less a complete circle and more of an arc. Figure 2 shows the invasion of the low humidity air into the core of Humberto in the 4500 to 8000 m layer. 

The Humberto analyses reveal at least one possible way that a hurricane can form. The work shows that a common feature associated with a line or group of cumulonimbi, the stratiform rain adjacent to the convective cells, can play a role in hurricane formation.
